s.gd: Nuair dh’fhairich Seonag deireadh a’ chàir a’ bualadh air a’ phòile-solais bha e mar gun cuireadh duine sgian na cridhe.
s.en: When Janet felt the rear of the car hitting the lampost it was as if someone had put a knife in her heart.

s.gd: ’Se a’ chiad rud a thàinig a-staigh oirre: “Ciamar a dh’innseas mi seo do Mhurchadh?
s.en: The first thing that came into her mind was: “How will I tell Murdo about this.

s.gd: Bha fios agam nach robh astar gu leòr eadar an dà chàr eile.
s.en: I knew that there wasn’t enough space between the two other cars.

s.gd: O carson a dh’fheuch mi ri faighinn a-staigh an seo?”
s.en: Oh why did I try to get in here?”

s.gd: Chunnaic i duine no dhà a’ toirt sùla oirre, agus feadhainn aca a’ gàireachdraich.
s.en: She saw one or two men looking at her, and a few of them laughing.

s.gd: Dh’fhairich i cho dearg ’s a bha a h-aodann air fàs.
s.en: She felt how red her face had become.

s.gd: Bha fhios glè mhath aice dè bhiodh iad a’ smaoineachadh: “Co ris a bhitheadh sùil agad agus boireannach aig a’ chuibhle?”
s.en: She knew very well what they would be thinking: “What would you expect with a woman at the wheel?”

s.gd: Ise a fhuair tron teast a’ chiad uair!
s.en: She who had got through the test the first time!

s.gd: Dh’fheuch i ris a’ chàr a chur dìreach ri oir a’ chabhsair gus am falbhadh an fheadhainn a chunnaic dè thachair agus i a’ leigeil oirre nach robh i a’ saoilsinn càil dheth.
s.en: She tried to put the car straight with the pavement’s edge so that those who had seen what had happened would go away, pretending that she thought nothing of it.

s.gd: An uairsin thàinig i a-mach agus choimhead i air deireadh a’ chàir.
s.en: Then she came out and she looked at the rear of the car.

s.gd: Cha robh an gnothach cho dona agus a shaoil i an toiseach ach bha e dona gu leòr.
s.en: The situation was not as bad as she had thought at first but it was bad enough.

s.gd: Bha tolg mòr anns a’ bhumpair aig deireadh a’ chàir.
s.en: There was a big dent in the bumper at the rear of the car.

s.gd: Cha bhitheadh am bumpair ceart gu bràth tuilleadh.
s.en: The bumper would never be right again.

s.gd: Cha mhòr nach robh i a’ caoineadh.
s.en: She nearly wept.

s.gd: An càr ùr às an robh Murchadh cho pròiseil!
s.en: The new car of which Murdo was so proud!

s.gd: ’Se latha grianach a bha ann nuair dh’fhàg i an taigh anns a’ mhadainn agus i a’ dèanamh air a’ bhaile.
s.en: It had been a sunny day when she had left the house in the morning and heading into the town.

s.gd: Bha i a’ faireachadh cho toilichte agus cho comasach a’ stiùireadh a’ chàir.
s.en: She had been feeling so happy and so confident driving the car.

s.gd: Thòisich i air òran a ghabhail agus an uairsin stad i air eagal gum bitheadh daoine ga saoilsinn neònach.
s.en: She started to sing a song and then she stopped lest people would be thinking her odd.

s.gd: Ach a-nis ged a bha a’ ghrian a cheart cho soilleir bha a h-uile càil air tionndadh cho grànda.
s.en: But now even though the sun was just as bright everything had turned so ugly.

s.gd: “Uill, tha e cho math dhomh dèanamh air na bùthannan,” thuirt i rithe fhèin.
s.en: “Well, I might as well head for the shops,” she said to herself.

s.gd: Ach bha a ceann ann an leithid a bhoil leis na thachair ’s gun theab i leth chlach ime agus leth phunnd buntàta iarraidh anns a’ chiad bhùth.
s.en: But her head was in such an excitement with what had happened that she nearly asked for half a stone of butter and half a pound of potatoes in the first shop.

s.gd: Thachair càirdean rithe ach is gann a dh’aithnich i iad leis mar a bha i a’ faireachadh.
s.en: Friends happened upon her and she scarcely recognised them with how she was feeling.

s.gd: Air an rathad dhachaigh bha i a’ fiachainn ri smaoineachadh ciamar a dh’innseadh i do Mhurchadh dè rinn i.
s.en: On the road home she was trying to think how she would tell Murdo what she had done.

s.gd: Bha e cho moiteil às a’ chàr agus cho pròiseil cuideachd gun d’fhuair ise tron teast a’ chiad uair a dh’fheuch i e, ged bhitheadh e a’ tarraing aiste agus ag ràdh gu robh e neònach gur e na boireannaich an còmhnaidh a bhitheadh a’ faighinn tron teast a’ chiad uair.
s.en: He was so proud of the car and so proud also that she had got through the test the first time she tried it, even though he would tease her and say that it was strange that it was the women who always got through the test the first time.

s.gd: Ciamar a thòisicheadh i air innse dha?
s.en: How would she begin to tell him?

s.gd: “A bheil cuimhne agad a Mhurchaidh nuair thuirt thu gun toireadh tu maitheanas dhomh airson rud sam bith nan toirinn pòg dhut?”
s.en: “Do you remember Murdo when you says that you would do me any favour at all if I would give you a kiss?”

s.gd: Ach bha amharas oirre nach bitheadh a’ bhuaidh aig a pògan air a-nis ’s a bha aca aon uair.
s.en: But she had a suspicion that the effct of her kisses on him now would not be what they once had been.

s.gd: No: “A bheil cuimhne agad, a Mhurchaidh an latha a phòs sinn agus na bòidean a rinn thu gun gabhadh tu mi airson a’ chuid as fheàrr neo a’ chuid as miosa?
s.en: Or: “Do you remember, Murdo the day that we married and the vows you made that you would take me for better or for worse?

s.gd: Uill, tha a’ chuid as miosa air tachairt.”
s.en: Well, the worst has happened.”

s.gd: An dèidh dhi faighinn dhachaigh thog i am fòn agus dh’fhaighnich i de mhuinntir garaids a bha faisg air làimh am b’urrainn iad bumpair ùr a chur air a’ chàr an latha ud fhèin.
s.en: After she got home she picked up the phone and asked the garage people who were nearby if they could put a new bumper on the car that same day.

s.gd: Thuirt iad nach b’urrainn dhaibh sin a dhèanamh ach dòcha gun dèanadh iad e an ath latha.
s.en: They said that they could not do that but maybe they would do it the following day.

s.gd: Ghabh i ris an tairgse sin agus chuir i sìos am fòn.
s.en: She accepted that offer and she put down the phone.

s.gd: “Eil fhios am faigheadh Murchadh a-mach mu dheidhinn mur innsinn idir dhà e?” thuirt i rithe fhèin.
s.en: “Do we know if Murdo would find out about it if I don’t tell him?” she said to herself.

s.gd: “Chan eil feum aige air a’ chàr is bithidh e a’ coiseachd dhan choinneimh a-nochd.
s.en: “He doesn’t need the car and he will be walking to the meeting this evening.

s.gd: Bhithinn a’ faireachadh slèagach ach ’s fheàrr sin na ’n aimhreit.”
s.en: I would feel sneaky but that is better than quarrelling.”

s.gd: Bha i a’ faireachadh beagan na b’fheàrr an dèidh dhi cur roimhpe nach innseadh i idir e agus thòisich i air a h-obair taighe le cridhe na b’aotroime.
s.en: She was feeling a bit better after deciding that she would not tell him at all and she started on her housework with a lighter heart.

s.gd: Ach cha robh e fada gus na thòisich a cogais air a buaireadh.
s.en: But it was not long unil her conscience started to trouble her.

s.gd: “Ma thòisicheas sinn air rudan a chumail bho chèile chan eil fhios càite an stad e.
s.en: “If we start keeping things from each other you don’t know where it will stop.

s.gd: Ma gheibh Murchadh a-mach gun cheil mi seo air goirtichìdh e gu mòr e.”
s.en: If Murdo finds out that I have concealed this from him it will hurt him a lot.”

s.gd: Na h-inntinn chunnaic i i-fhèin agus Murchadh ann an cùirt an dealachaidh agus am fear lagh ag ràdh, “’Se a’ chiad rud a thàinig eadar an dithis seo nuair thòisich a’ bhean air rudan a cheiltinn air an duine.”
s.en: In her mind she saw herself and Murdo in the divorce court and the lawyer saying, “The first thing that came between this couple was when the wife concealed things from the husband.”

s.gd: “’S fheàrr dhomh innse dhà,” smaoinich i mu dheireadh, “ged bhitheadh e fiadhaich fhèin.”
s.en: “I should tell him,” she thought at last, “even if he would be angry himself.”

s.gd: Thainig gnogadh dhan doras agus cò bha siud ach a deagh bana-charaid Catrìona.
s.en: A knock came on the door and who was there but her good froend Catherine.

s.gd: “Thig a-staigh, a Chatrìona.
s.en: “Come in, Catherine.

s.gd: Bheil fhios agad dè rinn mi?
s.en: Do you know what I did?

s.gd: Bhuail mì an càr air pòile is chan eil fhios agam ciamar a dh’innseas mi do Mhurchadh e.”
s.en: I hit the car on a pole and I don’t know how I will tell it to Murdo.”

s.gd: “Innse!
s.en: “Tell!

s.gd: Carson a dh’innseas tu e?
s.en: Why will you tell him?

s.gd: Nach cuir a’ gharaids ceart e?”
s.en: Won’t the garage fix it?”

s.gd: “Bhithinn a’ faireachadh cho slèagach ged tha,” fhreagair Seonag.
s.en: “I would feel so sneaky though,” Janet replied.

s.gd: “Faireachadh slèagach!
s.en: “Feeling sneaky!

s.gd: Nach tu tha gòrach.
s.en: Aren’t you silly.

s.gd: Nam bithinn-sa ag innse do Thormod a h-uile càil a tha mi a’ dèanamh ceàrr, bhitheadh bristeadh-pòsaidh air a bhith ann fada ro seo.
s.en: If I were to tell Norman everything that I do wrong, there would have been a divorce long before now.

s.gd: Cha dèan math a h-uile càil inse dha na fir.
s.en: It does no good to tell everything to men.

s.gd: Cha dèan e ach aimhreit is gheibh thusa sin a-mach luath gu leòr, a nighean.
s.en: It only makes a quarrel and you will find that out soon enough, girl.

s.gd: Chan eil e math dhaibh cus den fhìrinn a chluinntinn co-dhiù.”
s.en: It is not good for you to hear too much of the truth anyway.”

s.gd: Rinn Seonag gàire airson a’ chiad uair on thachair an tubaist.
s.en: Janet smiled for the first time since the accident happened.

s.gd: “Thugainn a-staigh dhan chidsin is gabhaidh sinn cupa tì,” ars ise.
s.en: “Let’s go inside to the kitchen and have a cup of tea,” she said.

s.gd: “Dèan thusa dìnneir mhath dhà agus na innis càil,” arsa Catrìona nuair bha i a’ falbh.
s.en: “You make him a good dinner and don’t say anything,” said Catherine when she was leaving.

s.gd: Ach bha Seonag eadar-dhà-bharail fad an fheasgair agus cha robh i air a h-inntinn a dhèanamh suas aig leth uair an dèidh còig nuair a dh’fhairich i an doras a-muigh a’ fosgladh agus Murchadh a’ tighinn a-staigh.
s.en: But Janet was in two minds all afternoon and she had not made up her mind at hald past five when she sensed the outside door opening and Murdo coming inside.

s.gd: “Bithidh do dhìnneir deiseil ann an tiotan, a Mhurchaidh, dh’èigh i.
s.en: “Your dinner will be ready in a bit, Murdo, she called.

s.gd: Faodaidh tu am pàipeir a leughadh thuige sin.”
s.en: You can read the paper till then.”

s.gd: “Dè chanas mi?” thuirt i rithe fhèin an dèidh dhi am biadh a chur a-mach, agus i a’ suidhe aig a’ bhòrd.
s.en: “What will I say?” she said to herself after she put out the food, and sitting down at the table.

s.gd: An uairsin thug i an aire gu robh bocsa beag air a chur air a beulaibh.
s.en: Then she noticed that a little box had been put in front of her.

s.gd: “Dè tha seo?” dh’fhaighnich i.
s.en: “What is this?” she asked.

s.gd: Agus an uairsin dh’fhosgail i e.
s.en: And then she opened it.

s.gd: “O Mhurchaidh, am broidse air an robh mi a’ coimhead Disathairne seo chaidh.
s.en: “Oh Murdo, the broach that I was looking at last Saturday.

s.gd: Carson a chosg thu do chuid airgid?”
s.en: Why did you spend your money?”

s.gd: “Uill,” arsa Murchadh.
s.en: “Well,” said Murdo.

s.gd: O Mhurchaidh,” thuirt i, “chuir mise tolg mòr am bumpair a’ chàir agad an-diugh.”
s.en: “Oh Murdo,” she said, “I put a big dent in the bumper of your car today.”

s.gd: Cha tuirt Murchadh guth.
s.en: Murdo did not say a word.

s.gd: Chaidh e a-null dhan dreasair agus thug e rudeigin às.
s.en: He went over to the dresser and took something out.

s.gd: Nuair thug e a-nall ga h-ionnsaigh e chunnaic i gur e an soitheach criostal a thug piuthar a màthar dhi a bha ann agus gu robh tè de na cluasan aige briste.
s.en: When he brought it over to her she saw that it was the crystal bowl that her mother’s sister had given her and that one of its handles was broken.

s.gd: “Uill!” bha i a’ dol a thòiseachadh, “an soitheach criostal a thug piuthar mo mhàthar dhomh...”
s.en: “Well!” she was going to start, “the crystal bowl that my mother’s sister gave me...”

s.gd: Chuimhnich i air a’ chàr agus thòisich i air gàireachdaich.
s.en: She remembered the car and she started to laugh.

s.gd: Thòisich Murchadh cuideachd.
s.en: Murdo began too.

s.gd: “Thill mi dhachaigh anns a’ chàr aig Iain,” ars esan, “a dh’iarraidh pàipearan a dh’fhàg mi a-staigh agus bhris mi an soitheach.
s.en: “I returned home in John’s car,” he said, “to get papers I had left inside and I broke the bowl.”

s.gd: Cha d’rinn mi ach a stobadh anns an dreasair gus an tiginn dhachaigh ’s an innsinn dè thachair.
s.en: I only pushed it in the dresser until I came home and mentioned what had happened.

s.gd: B’e an t-iongnadh nach fhaca tu e.
s.en: It was a surprise you didn’t see it.

s.gd: Tha mi uabhasach duilich.”
s.en: I am terribly sorry.”

s.gd: “Bha mo cheann ann an leithid a bhoil leis a’ chàr,” arsa Seonag, “no bha mi air fhaicinn.
s.en: “My head was in such an excited state with the car,” said Janet, “or I would have seen it.”

s.gd: Ach chan eil còir sam bith agamsa a bhith fiadhaich.
s.en: But I have no right at all to be angry.

s.gd: Tha an dàrna duine cho clibeach ris an duine eile.”
s.en: The second person is as clumsy as the other one.

s.gd: An dèidh na dìnneir nuair bha i na seasamh aig an uinneig a’ smèideadh ri Murchadh agus e a’ falbh gu coinneamh na comataidh bha i a’ faireachadh mar gun deach uallach a thogail dhith.
s.en: After dinner when she was stood at the window waving to Murdo as he was leaving for the committee meeting she was feeling as though a burden had been lifted from her.

s.gd: Ach thàinig rudeigin a-staigh oirre.
s.en: But something came to her mind.

s.gd: “Chan eil fhios ciamar a bhitheadh mur a bitheadh e-fhèin air an soitheach criostal a bhristeadh?”
s.en: “I don’t know how it would be if he himself hadn’t broken th crystal bowl?”

s.gd: Agus an uairsin thuirt i rithe fhèin: “Cha bhi mi ag innse a h-uile càil idir, rudan beaga co-dhiù.”
s.en: And then she said to herself: “I won’t mention everything at all, little thigs anyway.”
